title: Feb 2024 FQE - Paediatrics
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics (February 2024). Covers MCQs, SAQs, and Clinical Cases.

questions.question: Paediatrics is an independent and unique specialty. Which of the following is NOT CORRECT regarding the factors to consider in managing paediatric patients?

options.text: Children's response to illness is influenced by age
Health problems of children differ from those of adults
Management of childhood illnesses vary significantly from that of adults
The child is actually a mini adult and should be treated as such

questions.explanation: A fundamental principle of paediatrics is that children are NOT small adults. They have distinct anatomical, physiological, immunological, and developmental differences that require specialized care.
questions.hint: Think about the fundamental philosophy of pediatrics regarding adult medicine.

questions.question: Examination parameters may differ in children. Which of the following is TRUE as regards to physical examination in older children?

options.text: Pleural effusion gives a resonant note on percussion
Abdominal palpation should be done before auscultation
Ear Nose & Throat (ENT) examination should be done at the beginning of systemic examination
Apex beat is usually found in the 5th intercostal space mid clavicular line

questions.explanation: In older children (typically >7 years), the apex beat moves to the 5th ICS MCL (similar to adults). In younger children, it is in the 4th ICS. Pleural effusion causes dullness. Auscultation precedes palpation in abdominal exams. ENT exams are distressing and done last.
questions.hint: Consider the cardiac landmark changes with age.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a predisposing factor to birth injuries?

options.text: Use of forceps or vacuum extraction

questions.explanation: Multigravidity typically results in an easier, more elastic birth canal and is not a primary risk factor for birth trauma compared to primiparity or instrumental delivery.
questions.hint: Which maternal factor generally makes delivery easier rather than harder?

questions.question: You are asked to give a motivational talk on Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Which of the following is a benefit of KMC?

options.text: Results in additional cost to the hospital
Increases parental morale as they are actively participating in their child care
Has no risk for possible intubation

questions.explanation: KMC promotes bonding, improves parental confidence, reduces hospital costs, and improves weight gain.
questions.hint: Focus on the psychological benefit to the parents.

questions.question: In growth and development, which period is correctly matched to its stage?

options.text: Infancy and toddlerhood: Birth to 1 year

questions.explanation: The WHO defines adolescence as the period between 10 and 19 years of age.
questions.hint: This is the standard WHO definition for the teenage years.

questions.question: A healthy infant develops axillary lymphadenitis without suppuration following BCG vaccine. What is the appropriate plan of action?
questions.explanation: Non-suppurative BCG lymphadenitis usually resolves spontaneously. Interventions are not indicated unless there is suppuration or systemic disease.
questions.hint: Is intervention necessary for a benign vaccine reaction?

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding epiglottitis?

options.text: It is self-limiting and mother can be reassured
May be caused by fungus requiring antifungal therapy
Treatment comprises of antibiotics, humidified oxygen and adequate hydration
Prognosis with delayed treatment is good

questions.explanation: Epiglottitis is a bacterial medical emergency (usually Hib) requiring airway management and IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: This is a life-threatening bacterial infection of the upper airway.

questions.question: An infant with congenital heart disease is diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which sign is most specific to this age group?
questions.explanation: In infants, the cardinal signs of heart failure are tachypnea, tachycardia, and hepatomegaly. Subjective symptoms like palpitations or PND cannot be reported by infants.
questions.hint: What is the infant equivalent of dyspnea?

questions.question: In which of the following conditions are you likely to hear an innocent (flow) murmur?
questions.explanation: Severe anemia causes a hyperdynamic circulation and increased turbulence, producing a functional flow murmur.
questions.hint: High cardiac output states can cause flow murmurs.

questions.question: Which of the following is a calcium channel blocker used as a paediatric antihypertensive?
questions.explanation: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic.
questions.hint: Identify the drug class.

questions.question: Which of the following is a MAJOR criterion in the Modified Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever?
questions.explanation: Major criteria (JONES): Joints (Polyarthritis), O (Carditis), Nodules, Erythema marginatum, Sydenham's Chorea. The others are minor criteria.
questions.hint: Remember the acronym JONES.

questions.question: Which of the following is a PRE-RENAL cause of acute kidney injury?
questions.explanation: Pre-renal causes involve hypoperfusion (e.g., dehydration). AGN and thrombosis are intrinsic; crystals are post-renal or intrinsic.
questions.hint: Which option describes a lack of blood flow to the kidney rather than damage to the kidney itself?

questions.question: Which of the following is a PROTOZOAL cause of acute glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium malariae is a protozoan associated with Quartan Malaria Nephropathy.
questions.hint: Identify the parasite among the options.

questions.question: A 6-year-old child presents with massive oedema, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia. Which drug is appropriate for management?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture describes Nephrotic Syndrome. Corticosteroids (Prednisolone) are the mainstay of treatment.
questions.hint: This condition is an autoimmune process affecting the podocytes.

questions.question: A child presents with jaundice, pruritus (scratching), and pale white stools. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: Pale stools indicate cholestasis (obstruction of bile flow). Hepatitis B causes cholestatic hepatitis. Malaria causes hemolytic jaundice (dark stools).
questions.hint: Pale stools mean bile is not reaching the gut.

questions.question: A 3-day-old newborn presents with convulsions, severe jaundice, and inability to breastfeed. Bilirubin levels are dangerously high. What is the correct management?
questions.explanation: Symptoms of Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy (Kernicterus) require immediate Exchange Transfusion to rapidly lower bilirubin and prevent permanent brain damage.
questions.hint: When phototherapy is not enough and the brain is at risk.

questions.question: A peripheral blood film shows Microcytic hypochromic anaemia. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency causes small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) red blood cells.
questions.hint: The most common nutritional anemia.

questions.question: A 3-year-old weighing 12kg presents with severe anemia (Hb 4g/dl) and respiratory distress. How much WHOLE BLOOD would you transfuse?
questions.explanation: Dose for Whole Blood is 20ml/kg. 12kg * 20ml/kg = 240ml. (Packed cells would be 10ml/kg = 120ml).
questions.hint: Calculate 20ml per kg.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding sickle cell disease management?

options.text: The sickle cell crisis appears at birth
Blood transfusion is indicated in all sickle cell crisis
Iron supplement is administered to all sicklers
Hydroxyurea prevents sickling by promoting the production of HbF

questions.explanation: Hydroxyurea increases Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF), which interferes with HbS polymerization. Symptoms are rare at birth due to high HbF.
questions.hint: Which drug modifies the hemoglobin type?

questions.question: A full haemogram shows increased MCV and macrocytic blood film. The likely cause is:
questions.explanation: Macrocytosis (Large RBCs) is typical of Megaloblastic anemia caused by B12 or Folate deficiency.
questions.hint: Deficiency of these vitamins affects DNA synthesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a diagnostic investigation for leukemia?
questions.explanation: Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy are the definitive tests to diagnose leukemia.
questions.hint: Where are blood cells made?

questions.question: A 9-year-old with ALL is being prepared for chemotherapy. What is the priority management to prevent Tumor Lysis Syndrome?
questions.explanation: Allopurinol is used to prevent hyperuricemia associated with rapid tumor cell breakdown (Tumor Lysis Syndrome). Hyperhydration is also key.
questions.hint: This drug lowers uric acid levels.

questions.question: A likely complication of a child presenting with maculo-papular rash, red eyes, and fever (Measles) is:
questions.explanation: Measles Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis) is a common respiratory complication of measles.
questions.hint: Measles affects the respiratory tract significantly.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning HIV diagnosis in children?

options.text: DNA PCR is diagnostic of HIV in children less than 18 months
Positive HIV ELISA <18 months confirms infection
Antibody test at 6 months is conclusive
Virology test is needed for all ages

questions.explanation: Maternal antibodies persist up to 18 months, making antibody tests unreliable. DNA PCR detects the virus directly.
questions.hint: Antibody tests detect mother's antibodies, not the baby's infection status.

questions.question: A child presents with itchy skin lesions with crusts and pus, mostly on flexor regions. Other family members are affected. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Severe itching (especially at night), flexor distribution, and family history are classic for Scabies.
questions.hint: The itch is often worse at night and affects multiple family members.

questions.question: What drug can be used safely if needed during newborn resuscitation for persistent bradycardia?
questions.explanation: Adrenaline 1:10,000 is the primary drug used in neonatal resuscitation if heart rate remains <60 despite ventilation and compressions.
questions.hint: Epinephrine at a specific dilution.

questions.question: In which group of newborns is CPAP prophylaxis indicated?
questions.explanation: Grunting indicates respiratory distress and alveolar collapse. CPAP prevents collapse.
questions.hint: CPAP is for Respiratory Distress.

questions.question: Which one is NOT an indication for intubation/tracheostomy?

options.text: Acute laryngotrachobronchitis in severe respiratory distress
Acute severe tonsillitis without respiratory distress

questions.explanation: Airway intervention is reserved for obstruction or failure. Tonsillitis without distress does not require an artificial airway.
questions.hint: If the patient can breathe comfortably, do they need a tube?

questions.question: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis usually presents:

options.text: In the second half of the first month of life

questions.explanation: Presentation is typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age.
questions.hint: It's not immediate at birth but appears within a few weeks.

questions.question: In Pediatric orthopedics, a positive Barlow test is a feature of:
questions.explanation: Barlow and Ortolani tests screen for hip instability/DDH.
questions.hint: Screening for hip problems in newborns.

questions.question: A male newborn has a large bladder, palpable kidneys, and obstruction with proximal dilatation on cystourethrogram. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The classic triad for PUV is distended bladder, hydronephrosis, and dilated posterior urethra in a male infant.
questions.hint: Common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in boys.

questions.question: A newborn has mild hepatomegaly and urine culture grows CMV. What deficit is most likely to occur in the next year?
questions.explanation: Congenital CMV is the leading non-genetic cause of sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.hint: This sensory deficit is a hallmark of CMV sequelae.

questions.question: A 14-year-old has bilateral matted, non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy unresponsive to cephalexin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Matted, non-tender nodes (scrofula) are classic for TB Adenitis.
questions.hint: Matted nodes are the key keyword.

questions.question: An asymptomatic 8-year-old has microscopic hematuria on routine urinalysis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Asymptomatic microscopic hematuria in this age group often suggests mild/subclinical glomerulonephritis (e.g., IgA nephropathy or resolving post-strep GN).
questions.hint: Nephritic process without full blown symptoms.

questions.question: A 6-week old has gained no weight, has mottled skin, cold extremities, and indirect bilirubin of 24 mg/dl. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Galactosemia presents with FTT, jaundice, and E. coli sepsis (shock signs like mottling/cold extremities).
questions.hint: Metabolic disorder predisposing to gram-negative sepsis.

questions.question: The drug of choice for PCP (Pneumocystis) prophylaxis is:
questions.explanation: Cotrimoxazole (Septrin) is the standard for PCP prophylaxis.
questions.hint: Also known as Septrin or Bactrim.

questions.question: A 7-year-old has fever, cough, shortness of breath, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and eosinophilia. What organism is the likely cause?
questions.explanation: Loeffler's syndrome (eosinophilic pneumonia) is caused by Ascaris larval migration through the lungs.
questions.hint: A worm that migrates through the lungs causing eosinophilia.

questions.question: A 2-year-old develops a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor after a viral prodrome. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This is the classic presentation of Croup (Viral Laryngotracheobronchitis).
questions.hint: Barking seal cough.

questions.question: What cardiovascular feature is associated with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)?
questions.explanation: MVP and berry aneurysms are common extra-renal associations of ADPKD.
questions.hint: A valve issue.

questions.question: An 11-year-old boy presents with behavioral changes, sleep difficulty, decline in school performance, and a diffuse smooth goiter. What is the next management step?
questions.explanation: Symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism (Graves'). Thyroid function tests are diagnostic.
questions.hint: Test the function of the enlarged gland.

questions.question: A 2-year-old (12kg) presents with cough, difficulty breathing, lower chest indrawing, and cyanosis (SpO2 80%). This is Severe Pneumonia. Select the correct components of the initial treatment plan.

options.text: Give IV Benzylpenicillin and IV Gentamicin
Give Oral Amoxicillin and send home
Give IV Ceftriaxone as an alternative

questions.explanation: Severe pneumonia requires admission, oxygen, and IV antibiotics (Penicillin/Gentamicin or Ceftriaxone).
questions.hint: This is a medical emergency requiring inpatient care and parenteral antibiotics.

questions.question: A 6-year-old presents with reddish-brown urine and BP 138/95 mmHg. Select the correct diagnosis and relevant investigations.
questions.explanation: The presentation (Hematuria + HTN) is Nephritic Syndrome/AGN. ASOT confirms recent strep. Urinalysis confirms hematuria. Low C3 is typical.
questions.hint: Nephritic syndrome triad + post-strep markers.

questions.question: A preterm born at 34 weeks is stable and weighs 1.6kg at 4 days. Which vaccination recommendations are correct for this child?

options.text: Delay all vaccines until weight is 2.5kg

questions.explanation: Stable preterms should receive birth doses (Hep B, OPV). BCG is often given at discharge/stability.
questions.hint: Chronological age usually guides vaccination in stable preterms, not just weight.

questions.question: A 15kg child has Bacterial Meningitis. What is the correct dose of IV Ceftriaxone?
questions.explanation: Meningitis dose is 100mg/kg/day. 15kg * 100mg = 1500mg. Ceftriaxone is given OD.
questions.hint: Calculate 100mg/kg.

questions.question: A 14-year-old with Rheumatic Heart Disease presents with prolonged fever, splenomegaly, and splinter hemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Splinter hemorrhages, fever, and new murmurs/RHD history are classic for Infective Endocarditis.
questions.hint: Infection of the heart valves.

questions.question: A 7-month-old (4.5kg) with severe dehydration worsened after rapid IV fluids. Why?

options.text: The child has Severe Acute Malnutrition and cannot tolerate rapid sodium/fluid loads
The fluid was not given fast enough
The child needed whole blood instead
Antibiotics were not mixed with the fluid

questions.explanation: The child is severely wasted (4.5kg at 7m). SAM children have weak hearts and sodium retention; rapid IV fluids cause heart failure.
questions.hint: Malnourished heart + salt load = failure.

questions.question: A 12-year-old has weight loss despite good appetite, palpitations, and exophthalmos. What is the confirmatory test?
questions.explanation: Features are classic for Graves' Disease (Hyperthyroidism). TFTs confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Check the hormone levels.

questions.question: A 6-year-old presents with profuse sweating, agitation, priapism, and tachycardia after a scorpion sting. What is the specific antidote?
questions.explanation: Severe scorpion envenomation causes autonomic storm. Antivenom neutralizes toxin; Prazosin manages sympathetic overdrive.
questions.hint: Specific neutralization.

questions.question: CASE STUDY: A 3-year-old presents unconscious with fever, neck stiffness, and positive Kernig's sign. History of recent malaria treatment. Select the correct management steps.

richContent.content:
Scenario: Unconscious 3-year-old.
Signs: Fever, Neck Stiffness, Kernig's (+), Convulsions.
Impression: Meningitis (or Cerebral Malaria co-infection).

options.text: Perform Lumbar Puncture (after ruling out raised ICP)
Check Blood Sugar and treat hypoglycemia

questions.explanation: Management of Bacterial Meningitis: ABCs, LP for diagnosis, IV antibiotics (Ceftriaxone), Steroids (Dexamethasone), and supportive care (Glucose, Anticonvulsants).
questions.hint: Full meningitis protocol is required.
